ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

OVERSEAS AND LOCAL UNDERGRADUATES
(Difference in costs of subsidy)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mdm Ho Geok Choo -

    1. To ask the Minister for Education what is (i) the difference in the costs of subsidising undergraduates who are sent overseas for exposure to foreign entrepreneurial cultures and those who go through the normal course of study in our tertiary institutions; and (ii) the percentage of undergraduates being sent for such overseas stints relative to the total student population.

    Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): Question No. 1, Sir.

    The Minister for Education (RAdm Teo Chee Hean): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has actively encouraged an entrepreneurial spirit among Singaporeans. Our universities - the National University

Column: 961

of Singapore, Nanyang Technological University and the Singapore Management University - have responded to this call by promoting a culture of enterprise on campus by various means, for example, mounting relevant academic modules, establishing entrepreneurship centres and technology relations offices. These provisions are available to all students of the respective universities.

    The National University of Singapore has also launched the "NUS Overseas Colleges". This is a strategic programme aimed at providing a small number of select students the opportunity to be nurtured into dynamic and resourceful entrepreneurs by immersion in vibrant entrepreneurial hubs which are anchored by strong academic institutions. Students will be sent on a one-year stint to these overseas colleges to work as interns attached to high-tech start-ups, and attend entrepreneurship courses at partnering universities. NUS has to date set up two overseas colleges - in the Silicon Valley in partnership with Stanford University, and in the Bio Valley, in partnership with University of Pennsylvania. 38 students are currently in the Silicon Valley, and another 10 are expected to set off for the Bio Valley in January 2003. By 2010, NUS plans to send 250 students (or 4% of the average NUS annual cohort) each year to its overseas colleges.

    The additional cost incurred for a student who spends one year at an overseas college is about $35,500. About two-thirds of this cost is borne by the internship companies which our students are attached to. The other one-third is borne by the Government. Students on the programme therefore do not pay additional fees for the duration of their programme in the overseas college.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, once the students return from their overseas stint, I would like to ask the Minister if there are any programmes in place to allow them to continue to nurture their entrepreneurial spirit or mindset. Is there any programme in place to ensure

Column: 962

that in future when they graduate, this overseas stint would also be helpful in helping them to become entrepreneurs?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: As I have explained earlier in my answer, the universities do have a variety of programmes to help students set up companies if they are interested in doing so. They have incubators, technology relations offices and so on. Apart from that, the various economic agencies also have a variety of programmes available for not just graduating students but other Singaporeans who are interested in starting up their own companies or venturing into their own enterprises to go ahead to do so.

Column: 962

NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS
(Annotation of certificates for students given special
arrangements)


    2. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for Education (a) what is the rationale for his Ministry's recent requirement that students who need special arrangements or considerations for national examinations (PSLE, "O" and "A" levels) will have their certificates annotated with special symbols; (b) on a nationwide basis, how many of these students who sat for the national examinations last year had asked and were given such special arrangements or considerations for their examinations; and (c) what proportion of the total cohort do these numbers represent.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, before I ask Question No. 2, I would like to declare that I have a son who is dyslexic and is taking his PSLE examination this year.

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Mr Speaker, Sir, in every examination, there is a set of pre-determined conditions, for example, the duration of the examination, to ensure that all candidates are assessed on a common yardstick. Special arrangements, however, are made for certain candidates to allow them to take their examinations and demonstrate their mastery of the subject being examined without being disadvantaged by the special difficulties

Column: 963

that they have. By doing so, our intention is to open up opportunities for students with special needs to sit for and obtain qualifications at the various national examinations. And indeed, the number of such students who have been able to get such special arrangements has been rising. This will pave the way for them to proceed on to further education. The special arrangements that are made include giving the candidate additional time to write the examination, exempting him from aural/oral test and providing other forms of assistance that may be needed.

    In recent years, there has been a significant increase in the number of requests for special arrangements. For example, there was an increase of 39% in the requests received between 2000 and 2001, from 469 to 650. These requests come from candidates with a wide range of medical or psychological conditions of varying degrees of severity from mild to very serious. The determination as to whether a condition merits special arrangements, and the extent of special arrangements a disability merits, are not clear-cut, black and white decisions. The Ministry has therefore decided that an even-handed, transparent and fair approach be adopted. All candidates who have been granted special arrangements in an examination will have an annotation in their certificates. This annotation will indicate that these candidates have taken their examinations under conditions which are different from those who take the examinations under the normal prescribed conditions. The annotation will only state that the students sat for the examinations under special arrangements. No details of the special arrangements will appear on the certificate. The Ministry of Education will also not reveal details of the student's reasons for requesting the special arrangements unless the student authorises the Ministry to do so.

    This policy of annotation will ensure that even as we allow candidates who need special arrangements access to our examinations, we do so in a way that maintains transparency in our examination system and that the examination system is as fair as possible to those

Column: 964

students who take the examinations under the normal prescribed conditions. And that it is also fair to those small number of candidates each year who do have medical or psychological conditions which are serious enough to merit special arrangements.

    Last year, there were 216 students from the PSLE and 434 students from the GCE `N', `O' and `A' level examinations who applied for special arrangements. Of these, all the students from PSLE and 382 (88%) students from the GCE `N', O' and `A' levels who applied for special arrangements were given such special arrangements.

    These numbers represent about 0.43% of the total candidature for the 2001 PSLE and about 0.63% of the total candidature for the 2001 GCE `N', `O' and `A' level examinations.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister if the Ministry had considered the negative impact and consequences of annotation on these children in subsequent years, such as labelling and stigmatising, which could bring about a further reduction of opportunities for these children for mainstreaming and integrating into the society and hence, increase the obstacles for independent living, when all that such disadvantaged students are asking for is accommodation to help them level up.

    Secondly, did the Ministry discuss the issues with the relevant organisations such as the Society for the Deaf and DAS before implementing the annotation policy?

    Finally, besides the US, which are the other countries that practise annotation or flagging?

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Sir, the Ministry considered the matter very seriously and we decided to adopt a balanced and open approach. We recognise that there are students who have medical or psychological problems who will be able to sit for and do well in their PSLE, GCE 'O', 'A' and 'N' level examinations.

Column: 965

because we want to give these students an opportunity to take these examinations that we provide this accommodation.

    Sir, there is no question about not providing accommodation. The Ministry is prepared to provide accommodation where there is proper medical and psychological assessment and the Ministry considers that these reasons are strong and serious enough to merit special arrangements. That will continue.

    On the other hand, we have to balance this against fairness to other candidates who may not have asked for special arrangements to take their examinations under normal circumstances. The range of requests has increased over the years. In the early years, we have had very clear-cut requests - generally, physical disabilities for which there is very little doubt one way or the other. But in recent years, we have received a larger number of requests, mainly of a psychological nature for which the severity and the precise nature of the requests require much more judgement, and even the medical and psychological professionals do not always agree on them. So what we want to do is to balance this desire to accommodate more of such requests which are valid together with the need to be more open and balanced with regard to having agreed to these requests. We believe that this is a fair and open system by which students who have conditions which are serious enough will be able to get access to special arrangements and allow them to proceed on to higher education.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister to comment on the number of students who have been asking for special accommodation which has increased over the years. Would it not be fair to say that previously, most parents would not be so informed as to the types of disabilities that our children could suffer from but with society maturing and becoming more sophisticated and informed, some of these disabilities which were previously not detectable or the parents would not know about it ---

Column: 966



    Mr Speaker: Dr Khor, could you make your questions concise, please?

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: I would like to ask the Minister to comment that perhaps the Ministry could look at it from the point of view that the number has increased because of information access.

    My other question is: why did the Ministry actually implement the annotation policy at a time when the College Board of the US has just agreed to stop flagging the scores of disabled students who take the SAT under special conditions, such as extra time? From what I read about the practice of flagging in the US, one of the reasons for flagging is to prevent abuse by students who, in reality, have no real disabilities.

    Mr Speaker: Dr Khor, you are making a speech again.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: No, I am asking a question. This links to the question that I am asking now. If indeed one of the primary objectives of the Ministry is to prevent this abuse, can the Ministry consider instead to implement more stringent conditions under which a student can have special accommodation? For example, recognising tests ---

    Mr Speaker: Dr Khor, if you do not ask your question, I will ask you to resume your seat.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Yes, this is the question. I would like to ask the Ministry if they can consider recognising tests from, say, accredited panels so that the Ministry can be assured that these are students who have real disabilities and are asking for special accommodation.

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Sir, Dr Khor is indeed correct. As I have said earlier, there is an increasing number of conditions which have now been recognised for which students are asking for special accommodation. So, the increase in the requests for special accommodation do come from this wider range of conditions. Not all these conditions are completely well established. Even among the medical

Column: 967

professionals and the psychologists, there may be some disagreement as to the impact of these conditions on the examinations which the student is taking, and they may well disagree also on the extent and whether or not accommodations are justified. So the Ministry is, in a sense, in a rather difficult position. And even the doctors, whom the parents who bring their children/students to, are also in a difficult situation, because the parents, obviously, would want doctors to certify their children/students and would bring such certifications to the Ministry.

    For some of these conditions, there is no clear-cut decision one way or the other. And the kinds of accommodations the Ministry can make have to be of a rather coarse nature. We cannot say that with this condition, we will give you two minutes extra time per hour. This other condition, three minutes, four minutes or five minutes. It is very difficult to make such fine adjustments. Basically, where there is a request for extra time, generally, we give a student about 15 minutes extra per hour. So this is a coarse assessment, and we are unable to make such fine assessments.

    The differentiation between mild, moderate and serious is very judgmental. Basically, what the Ministry has decided is that if the student feels that the condition is serious enough to merit special arrangements, and if that is the case, then we ought to annotate it, because the condition is serious enough.

    Dr Khor asked what other countries practise annotation. Annotation is practised in the UK as well. The UK Examinations Board does so. Dr Khor is right that the College Board which runs the SAT 1 in the US has recently been ordered by the courts in the US to stop annotation. Dr Khor is also correct that there have been concerns raised about whether this will cause abuse of the system. If I may quote from an article in the New York Times of 15th July by Tamar Lewin entitled "Abuse is feared as the SAT test changes disability policy". It says:

    "High school guidance counsellors have said that the elimination of flagging could set off a wave of new applications for accommodations, including some from students without disabilities."

Column: 968



    It goes on to say:

    "Some college admission officers too say they worry about how the change will play out and whether it will lead to so many requests for extended time that ultimately everyone will be allowed four or five hours on a 3-hour exam."

    So, there are real concerns about abuse, and it is very difficult to make a judgment on these situations. Because some of the conditions are quite new ones which are not completely well understood even by the professionals.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether the Ministry is aware that in countries where annotation is practised, such as in the US, the level of special accommodation is generally higher. For instance, a dyslexic child is not only given 50% extra time, say, in the SAT test, but is also given a reader to read the questions, and a writer to write the answers as directed by the student.

    I would also like to ask whether the Minister could actually reconsider the accommodation provided to such students, to see whether the same level of accommodation can be given since annotation is here to stay. So, it is not just a negative impact that the disabled student would receive. In addition, he would be able to level up.

    RAdm Teo Chee Hean: Sir, my Ministry is prepared to make special accommodations. And the kind of special accommodations which we are prepared to make include extra time allowance, modified question papers, exemptions from certain components of a subject, eg, aural/oral test, the use of readers and the use of practical assistants as well, particularly where a student has physical disabilities which make it difficult for the student to write or to manipulate a piece of equipment. We have Braille question papers; we have enlarged print and so forth. Basically, the objective is to try and make the examinations more accessible to students with these kinds of conditions. But, at the same time, we need to balance this with having a more open and transparent system, so that students who offer reasons which they consider serious

Column: 969

enough to merit special consideration would also have this annotated in the certificate.

Column: 969

HORMONE REPLACEMENT THERAPY


    The following Question stood in the name of Mdm Halimah Yacob -

    3. To ask the Minister for Health in view of a recent American report which cast serious doubts about the safety of Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT), can his Ministry confirm whether (i) HRT is safe; (ii) there are studies done in Singapore to determine the impact of HRT on women and, if so, what are the findings; (iii) it has checked with the World Health Organisation on the safety of HRT; and (iv) there are HRT alternatives for women and are these made available at Government clinics and restructured hospitals.

    Mr Arthur Fong (West Coast): Sir, Question No. 3.

    The Minister of State for Health (Dr Balaji Sadasivan) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) refers to the use of prescription drugs to "replace" the hormones that the ovaries stop making at the time of menopause. The short-term use of HRT to relieve menopausal symptoms and improve quality of life is established. This benefit is recognised by the World Health Organisation.

    There had been past studies which suggested that long-term HRT use could reduce the risk of heart attacks and hip fractures due to osteoporosis. On the other hand, there had also been studies which associated long-term HRT use to breast and ovarian cancers and pulmonary embolism.

    The Women's Health Initiative (WHI) study in the United States is the first randomised control trial, or the "gold standard" in studies on effectiveness, in the world to study the potential benefits of

Column: 970

long-term HRT use. The study was terminated early as health risks exceeded health benefits. For every 10,000 women using combined HRT at the prescribed dosages in the study for one year, there would be seven more heart attacks, eight more breast cancers, eight more strokes and eight more pulmonary emboli compared to six fewer colorectal cancers and five fewer hip fractures.

    There have been no randomised control trials on HRT done in Singapore. The Ministry of Health will appoint a specialist group to develop practice guidelines for doctors on HRT. Depending on the indications for HRT treatment, there are alternative treatments available at polyclinics and restructured hospitals. The Ministry of Health advises women on HRT to consult their doctors regarding their treatment.

    Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): Sir, may I ask the Minister of State whether it is correct to say that many HRT products contain different compounds in different dosages? Therefore, should the WHI result, mentioned earlier by the Minister of State, be applied to any other HRT products other than the one investigated in the trial? Am I correct to say that market research confirms that the relief of menopausal symptoms is the number one reason why women take HRT? But the effects of the HRT product on menopausal symptoms and the quality of life were not measured in the WHI trial. Should this not be included in any comprehensive trial?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Sir, Dr Neo is correct that there are quality of life issues involved in the use of HRT, and the long-term treatment of HRT should be individualised to the patient. That is why the Ministry of Health feels that individual patients must consult their doctor regarding the appropriateness of the treatment.

Column: 970

DISABLED AND AGEING POPULATION
(Transportation needs)


    4. Assoc. Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang asked the Minister for Transport (a) what are the difficulties his Ministry faces in ensuring that the public transportation needs of the

Column: 971

disabled and an increasingly ageing population in Singapore can be met, as befitting a world-class transport system, and (b) what steps his Ministry has taken and will take to overcome the difficulties.

    The Senior Minister of State for Transport (Mr Khaw Boon Wan) (for the Minister for Transport): Mr Speaker, Sir, our public transport system strives to meet the needs of the elderly and the disabled. Wherever practicable, we ensure that the system is user-friendly and accessible to them. However, in making such an accommodation, we have also to take into account the needs of the large majority of commuters who require a speedy mode of transport.

    First, trains. For the Rapid Transit System, LTA has, since 1995, required all new MRT projects to comply with the "Code On Barrier-Free Accessibility In Buildings". This 1995 Code sets out the provisions and requirements of building facilities and fixtures, eg, ramps, toilets, lifts, public telephones, signages, to meet the needs of the disabled. Hence, newer stations, such as those coming up in the North East Line and the MRT Extension to Changi Airport are in compliance with this 1995 building Code.

    In addition, the LTA has embarked on a major exercise to retrofit the existing stations with lifts, ramps and toilets to make them user-friendly for commuters with disabilities. This exercise is estimated to cost the Government about $82 million. When completed, the entire MRT system will be fully disabled-friendly.

    In the case of public buses, LTA mandates that they must have low floor boards so as to facilitate easier boarding by the elderly and those with mild disabilities. Unfortunately, we are not able to require our public buses to kneel or come with special boarding equipment for those who are on wheelchairs. This is because our public bus services are meant for the rapid transportation of the masses. The priority is to speed up boarding and alighting. Making our public buses cater to the needs of the wheelchair-bound will impact this priority. This will affect the

Column: 972

cost and service level to the large majority of the commuters.

    A better way to address the needs of the wheelchair-bound is to provide a dedicated service for them. The Ministry of Community Development and Sports (MCDS) has therefore set up an Inter-Ministry Workgroup to look into this problem. It is led by the National Council of Social Services. My Ministry and LTA are represented in the Workgroup. And I understand that the Workgroup is in the process of finalising its recommendations.

    Assoc. Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang (Nominated Member): Sir, it is one thing to have the infrastructure, except for the public bus transport system, but it is another to make it affordable for the disabled and the increasingly ageing population to utilise the public buses. What schemes are in place for the affordability of those who cannot access the public buses and would have to take other forms of transportation, eg, taxis? Because the increased cost of looking after and maintaining oneself, if one is disabled, is compounded by expensive transport costs if no public transport means are available.

    Mr Khaw Boon Wan: Sir, how we should assist Singaporeans who are disabled and, at the same time, financially disadvantaged is a larger topic. I think it is best addressed holistically. I believe this is the purview of my colleagues in MCDS working with NCSS and the various VWOs. Whether financial assistance for them is best focused on transport needs, medical treatment or skills training can then be examined on an overall basis. In my Ministry's primary focus, we have to target at the rapid transportation of the masses. We will as far as practicable accommodate, be sensitive and sympathetic to those commuters with disabilities. And I think we have been improving over the years, as I elaborated earlier.

    Assoc. Prof. Ngiam Tee Liang: As public transport operators, the bus companies, is there an obligation on their part to provide this service to the public at large, and that includes the disabled and the elderly? If so, what measures is LTA having to ensure

Column: 973

that the obligations of a public bus operator include helping financially, or in other ways, the disabled and the elderly? Otherwise, the cost will be passed on to the individual families and the disabled themselves or the VWOs, who are already burdened with finding enough funds for the other services that they run.

    Mr Khaw Boon Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know whether the Member was in this House when we had a very robust debate about transport fares and the role of bus operators. I think we all know that they are commercial entities, they have to make ends meet. My Ministry is just a regulator of these licensees. They have to make ends meet, and whether they should subsidise a particular segment of their passengers or commuters, we know that finally the overall cost has to be borne by the rest of the commuters. If Singaporeans, the majority of the commuters, are prepared to cross-subsidise the other smaller segment of the population who are disabled, then that is a different consideration.

    But, as I said, the overall issue of how we should assist financially the disabled Singaporeans is a larger issue because their needs go beyond transport. There may be medical needs and there may be other occupational training needs. I think it is best looked at holistically and the appropriate Ministry to look at that, I believe, is MCDS. I am just a SMS, Ministry of Transport.

    Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member): Under the directions of the Ministry in wanting a world-class transport system as well as a seamless transport system, how would the Ministry account for a good MRT system that is currently disabled-friendly in terms of those in wheelchairs? When they get out of the MRT, there is not a good public transport system as in buses to help them. Would the Ministry be looking into perhaps a greater advisory role where the PTC is concerned in this matter?

    Mr Khaw Boon Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I share the Member's wish to make our

Column: 974

system as user-friendly to all and sundry. After all, every Singaporean matters. If they are unfortunate, have certain disabilities, we hope that we can also include them in the transport system. I think that is an ideal that we should always strive for. But to achieve such an ideal requires the part to be played by many parties. It is not just Government. The corporate sector is also involved. The NGOs are involved. The people themselves are involved, and even within the Government, different Ministries are involved. companies in these industries to be competitive, they must build up their size to enjoy the economies of scale, build up the depth of management expertise, attract talent and grow the company.
